description.text:
This is an improved version.
You should not need any supportmaterial now, but I didn't test it yet.

Theeth now horizontally printable, what makes them stronger when digging through the dirt because of the layer orientation.

Connection holes in teeth and bucket are now a lot stronger.

ObererRollenhalter requires a really good bed adhesion, otherwise it could tip over.

This is still heavily in development.
I plan to include an arduino, motors and stuff to make it remote controllable via a smartphone app.
For now, only the bucket of the final thing is aviable.
For printsettings, please refer to the pictures (they are in german tough)

If you have any questions or problems, don't hesitate to leave a comment!

You need:

2x Steel rod, Ø3 (Connects the teeth with the bucket)

2x M3x8 HEXAGON SOCKET SCREW ISO 4762 Connects Bucket with the U-shaped holder

2x M3x6 HEXAGON SOCKET SCREW ISO 4762 Connects Bucket with chain (String in my case, since i don't have such a small chain)

Note: I used the leftover screws from my 3D printer
The holes for the M3 screws have a diameter of 2,7mm.(all are located on the bucket)
I used a M3 threader because the printer can't print such small things as precise as needed here.

Translation:

Bucket: Schleppschaufel.stl
U-shaped holder: Buegel.stl
teeth: Zaehne.stl

author: victimiz3d

title: Scalable Cutting mat - Laser cut edition
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I recently needed a cutting mat for on my workbench. So I started designing and this is what I came up with. This model can be scaled to any size you want your cutting mat to be. All the features included in the model will automatically change when you change the equations file. There also a lot of options for customizing your cutting mat.

This scalable cutting mat is the first ever made.

Perks

  • Easy to make in all kinds of materials.
  • Easy to scale/size the model due to the use of equations.
  • Many customization options
  • No conversion of 2D drawings to ai files needed for the standard versions.
  • Easy to make your own changes to the model

Please note that the model has a lot of patterns and equations which tend to make it a little slow when rebuilding. I recommend, when changing the model, to change the equations file first. Then start up the file and go do something else for a couple of minutes.

Scaling
The model needs to be scaled using the equations file. When you decide to change the model you will need to make a new drawing. A good tutorial for that is found here. www.youtube.com/watch?v=hZrGLonrpt8&t=191s

Converting
A handy tip for converting the drawings to Adobe Illustrator is to change the border colors to blue, since there are a lot of border lines within the cutting mat. In SOLIDWORKS go to System options/colors/visible model edges. You can also use Inkscape for editing the drawings.

I currently haven't made it yet but I will upload photos as soon as I made it. When you decide to make one please send me a photo. I would love to see it made.

When there is something wrong with the model please let me know so I can fix it as soon as possible.

Notes
Interested in buying one please contact me via the GrabCAD messenger. I could also include a custom engraving into the model. The price depends on the size and shipping costs. Don't worry I won't charge much since I love to build stuff.

Thanks to Jonathan_K1906 for the pictures

description.text:
Multi-Color Cell Model

This multi-color model of a cell shows how 3D printing can be beneficial in the educational and medical spaces. Not only does it show different levels of the cells, but the different colors highlight areas of interest.

This model is intended to be printed all at once with a multi-material printing system like Palette+.

This mini model can be printed in separate parts and glued together: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2803322

Take a look at our other educational/medical print ideas:

MRI Scan Brain Model
Multi-Material Flexible Pliers
Bookworm Bookmark
Owl Bookmark
Dissolvable 3-Gear Train
Multi-Color Pen

For more prints, see our Ideas page.

comments.author: 3dprintgeekshop

comments.text:
Chloroplasts. In animal cells, the mitochondria produces the majority of the cells energy from food, and this model has the mitochondria
The Cell Wall. Another structural difference between in plant cells is the presence of a rigid cell wall surrounding the cell membrane, and the plant cell would have a larger cell wall. Vacuoles. Vacuoles are large, liquid-filled organelles found only in plant cells, and this model does not have a vacuole. tl:dr this is an animal cell.

You can do a similar process to merge the files in versions of Cura 2.x. If you have any questions, please feel free to send us a message at [email protected]!

remixed_from.title: Rogue One Star Wars Cassian's Blaster Side Detail

description.text:
MK2 can be found here https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2688776

This is a modular rifle system based on the A280 & A300 blasters for Rogue One. You can swap out the barrels and stocks to fit your configuration. You just need to use a 3/4in PVC pipe.

Edit: 8/31/17: Increased the size of the hole in the stock to match the barrel opening.

I have included the full large pieces and smaller sections for smaller printers.

Credit:
This was mostly a group effort. The base handle/receiver part started out as model I found in the SketchUp warehouse from Derik V. I modified it to be 1 solid piece and to make it work in this system. The large barrel, big stock & scope came from Coozco here. He handed them over and I modified them to work and make them a bit more accurate. The small plug and the side greebles are from Jswaggs models. I just made them to fit.

comments.text: So I need to buy a pipe which I will put to the middle of the gun to be more strong?

comments.text: Ronan75, I really like the work all of you have done on this model and I have done a few more modifications myself if you would be interested in the files.  I did not post them as it is based off of your work and I don't want to take any credit away from where it is due.  I have however changed the way in which the model prints by re-assembling it in 3d and then cutting it up more length wise instead to preserve the detail of the model print without using supports on anything.  I have also redesigned the stock to resemble the concept art done by Matthew Savage for the A300 and DLT-20A from Rogue One as well as make it adjustable by it being able to slide in and out similar to a AR-15.  I am getting ready to setup my first print now and am quite anxious to see the results.  Thanks for the upload and work you have put in on this!

description.text:
The cover of the butter box in my fridge broke and my wife threw it away. So I needed to make a complete new one. It doesn't look equal, but it works.
The original is a bit bigger than this one, but for me it is enough to not print another one.

My fridge is a Siemens KI23L74/33, but there can be a lot of Bosch, NEFs and so on which uses the same part (00265198). Original costs including shipping in Germany <30€.
http://www.siemens-home.bsh-group.com/de/shop-produktliste/00265198

I glued in one of the pins, the other one sticks fine as is.

Creality CR-10

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.3

Infill:

15%

Notes:

You need 2 of the pins
Designed with Fusion 360

This frame is for the inductrix blade micro quad. No extra hardware is needed, you can mount the battery either above the FC like in the picture or below (mouting holes are included). I didn't use the rubber spacers included on the original frame, and just screwed the board directly to the frame. I've tried a variety of mounting methods for underneath the frame, but found that each one was too thick and was keeping the quad from sitting level when you first power it on (making the self leveling feature in safe mode go crazy). Wanted to keep the mounting versitile in case I wanted to use a bigger 1S battery that isn't the same form factor as the stock battery. May try a rubber band to hold the battery in as well.

I am going to play around with a snap fit piece to cover the FC and have more mounting holes for the battery.

Frame came in around 2g

Newer version. Hard to say where the spring part will be most effective.

This is editable in Orchard, so the spring part can be relocated.
https://3dorchard.com/app/single/58ba2ea8c5c1b30ce4ce4c0f/5994e8656dd11d0be4c27835
Change tabs, scale, depth, etc.
I did a test print and the PLA is holding its shape very well so far. I'll move the spring outward, which should help keep the 'jaws' more aligned, which I want.

'Functionable' is a word I am using here because I think 'print-in-place' is too vague, and
up to now, the word was just bad English, but 3D printing now gives the word a clear meaning.
That meaning being: Operable directly from the print bed. Spread the word lol. Thanks.

description.text:
A stand for the Nintendo Switch in the form of a miniature arcade cabinet.

Bond all components EXCEPT the Top. The Top is made to slide on/off in order to insert/remove the Nintendo Switch Console.

For a cabinet without charging capability, one of each of the following is required:
-Top
-Simple Bottom and Front
-Simple Cradle
-Simple Back
-Left Side
-Right Side
-Filler

For a cabinet with charging capabilities, one of each of the following is required:
-Top
-Bottom and Front
-Cradle
-Back
-Left Side
-Right Side
-Filler

description.text:
3D Printed Case for GEMMA M0
If you're working on a project using the Adafruit GEMMA M0, you may want a case to protect it. This simple two piece enclosure can house the PCB and a 150mAh lithium ion polymer battery.

Portable GEMMA M0
The PCB is secured to two standoffs with M2.5 (6mm long) screws. We have a nice assortment of M2.5 sized nylon screws and nuts that will work well. The case allows access to the microUSB port for powering and programming. A slide switch extension allows you to power the GEMMA M0 on and off. To keep the case (relatively) slim, an opening on the cover lets the JST connector poke through the top.

https://learn.adafruit.com/gemma-m0-case/overview

author: grinsepeter

description.text:
Jedi amulet

One smooth and one rough version

Almost everyone that has a heated bed has had problems with the heat bed cable on the Trinus. This is a custom designed wire chain that eliminates the fatigue issue. Print two anchor links and a dozen middle links. They can be in PLA (as mine are), but PETG is less likely to break when you snap the links together. Once assembled, the chain is under no stress, so the PLA is fine. You do need a cable about twice as long as that supplied by Kodama, so I made my own. The connector specs are published in the Facebook Trinus Creatives forum, or you can message me. Assemble the two anchor links so that the anchor tabs are on the same side of the chain. One gets wire tied to the heat bed where you used to wire tie the cable. I affixed the other end to the metal base with double sided tape.

license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is an adjustable LED lamp that is large enough to accommodate two sections of a 5050 LED strip that measure 10mm x 50mm each (totaling 10mm x 100mm together). This is six LEDs.

Hardware: You will need two to three 12mm long M3 screws, and two to three 2.2mm thick M3 nuts (depending on the number of points of articulation you choose). I used cheese head screws. The mount attaches to the printer with the screw that came with the printer.

LED Arm Options: There are two of these that you can choose to print from. Light-LED_Arm.stl requires you to print Light-Angle_Connector.stl to attach to the connector arm, and gives you an extra point of articulation. If you decide that you don't need this extra movement, you can simply print Light-LED_Arm-With_Angle_Connector.stl.

Connector Arm Options: There are two of these that you can choose to print from: a honeycomb pattern or a triangle pattern.

Knobs: Print the knobs separately from all other parts. You will need to pause the print part way through so that you can insert M3 nuts, and then continue the print.

Check out the enclosure I created for the Monoprice Select Mini that lets you bring in a second power source and install switches to turn LEDs and/or fans on and off.

UNTESTED... print at your own risk.

Printed and tested this on a 1000KV brushless motor connected to a 3S battery. Stock propeller could generate around 750g (that's grams) of thrust while this only managed to generate around 600g. The _allungato version should have more surface area and thus generate more thrust although I haven't explicitly measured it yet.

I recommend printing and using this propeller to newbies trying to learn. On your first few flights you'll break countless of those and being able to cheaply produce them with your 3d printer makes it slightly less disappointing when your plane inevitably crashes in the ground.

PS: according to your slicer settings and the amount of support you print this with, the propeller may come out slightly unbalanced. Simply search on youtube how to balance a propeller and you should get it perfect in no more than 15 minutes.

Drop me a comment if you have any questions.

title: SBR Cone fitted for Tennis ball

description.text:
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/3yfbnhfVHxR

For launching Soda (Coke) Bottles by compressed air and water. This print provides a tennis ball to be added for weight when the water is expended after launching and the fins keep it flying straight. A ring at the bottom holds one end of the rubber bands and the other end on the fins. The bands also provide some flexibility. The raises inside the cone are for matching up with the indention's in the bottom of the bottle. The ring prints inside the cone.

description.text:
The baseplate of the MP15-22 22lr rifle clips, just kidding magazines, are held in place by a small plastic part. That part is under spring tension as the base plate slides away and will fly away. I know. I made replacement parts since it is a trivial part, and decided to make it so that the spring end threads through so the part can't fly away.

I've included two versions. One is the part itself and the other is the part divided in half and ready to print on a flat bed and be glued together. The two-part is the only one I've printed.

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Play

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.4 Nozzle

Infill:

80%

Notes:

Sliced in Cura 2.5 at 0.2 layers. 20mm/s speed for infill and 10 for walls and top and bottom. Those speed were bumped up to 120% in Repetier since they were too slow.

Temperature for Tglase Red was 235.

Bed Temp 70

Buildtak with school glue stick.

PS It made me choose Play above, I don't know why.

Assembly

For the split model, just apply glue to the flats and clamp together. The Tglase seems to work with super and gorilla glue, with the gorilla glue needed trimming due to foaming. Other plastics and glues can be used.

description.text: A 2D curved-geometry library for OpenSCAD. Requires concat support (OpenSCAD 2014.0x or newer). Included in this thing is example output produced from inflectum/tests/inflectum_test.scad. The library is hosted on github at https://github.com/audley/inflectum Update: New version of library (v1.1) now supports radii overrides, multiple radii (radii interpolation) and automatic radii.

comments.text: Update: Repository name has been changed from "Inflectum" to "inflectum". Small change, although it better follows the naming scheme of OpenSCAD libraries...
comments.author: audley

comments.text: Nice! I see that the examples are all on the X/Y plane. Can your library also apply to nodes spaced in 3 dimensions and not on a plane?
comments.author: laird

comments.text: Read the code - it's all 2D. Still, there's an amazing amount of functionality in this library! Impressive!
comments.author: laird

comments.text: Yes - it's just 2D. Getting it to work with nodes specified in 3D may be possible, but the solution is not obvious (to me) at the current point in time (and it may simply take to long to generate anyway). What may be possible would be specifying the nodes on a plane, and yet still generate 3D versions of the nodes and links. Perhaps the ability to linearly extrude between two planes with a given distance between them would also be useful.
comments.author: laird

comments.text: It struck me that you could approximate a 3D network of nodes by rendering a 2D network for each triplet of connected nodes, since 3 points define a plane. Not sure how to do that given OpenSCAD's limitations (variables that can't vary) but perhaps...

title: Freak 360 - a true 360 fan duct for Kossel printers
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Freak 360 - a true 360 fan duct

I've been having an Anycubic Kossel with that ugly fan duct that cools only from one side for a while now... I printed few version of what were supposed to be 360 degrees cooling ducts but all of them have a stronger air flow on one side.
After a few attempts to find a better cooling duct I decided to create it my own and there you have it: Freak 360.

This print need to be AIRTIGHT so print it from 0.2 down with a slow speed, supports on buildplate only.

Once you get it off the buildplate remove the supports from the back and from the bottom, this operation needs a bit of time because you DO NOT want to punch a hole in the duct.

The correct way to mount it is to screw in place the closest screws to the nozzle half the way trough then slide it in place and secure it with the other 2 screws. you might need to adjust the front screws before tightening the ones in the back.

The Freak 360 will be a nice upgrade for your Kossel.

I'm very happy with how it turned out to work, please share your prints and like this fan duct if you find it useful.

Printer:

Anycubic Kossel

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

<= 0.2

Notes:

This print need to be airtight so print it from 0.2 down with a slow speed, SUPPORTS TOUCHING BUILDPLATE ONLY.

Once you get it off the buildplate remove the supports from the back and from the bottom, this operation needs a bit of time because you DO NOT want to punch a hole in the duct.

If you feel lazy you can leave the supports at the bottom of the tubes and remove just the ring from the center.

title: Spiralized Bulbasaur
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Based on the low-poly Bulbasaur by FLOWALISTIK (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:327753), and inspired by this video (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HgY7ovYWplg).

This produces a 'spiralized' (like a Slinky toy) version of the Bulbasaur that is very satisfying to play with. There is a 0.25mm spiral cut through the whole body of Bulbasaur. When printed at 0.15mm layer heights, the spiral becomes a weak layer and can be split with a scraper or knife.

I hope to make the other starter Pokemon soon.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.15mm

Infill:

10%

Notes:

I have not tried smaller layer heights and they may work but larger are unlikely. Use only buildplate supports to avoid supports inside the spiral layers. This model is unlikely to scale well.

I printed it fine in ABS even with a little warping.

After printing you can split the spiral using a knife or scraper. i found that the layers come apart quite easily even if they look fused. be careful not to break the top of the head or the top of the bulb. There are some thinner parts that could break if you use too much force.

author: amcolley

description.text:
Hey, I am a designer without a printer..yet. So if my models need a bit of changing, let me know and I will try to fix it the best I can. Thanks! Don't forget to share pictures if you print my models!

Print 2 of the Slider Blocks, and one Base and one Arm.
The Base has a 45-degree overhang, so add support accordingly.

Assembly:

  1. Slide the Blocks into each axis of the cutout in the Base.
  2. Set arm on top of the Blocks and insert tooth pick (or 2mm alike object) through the hole of the Arm into the hole of the Block. Push the toothpick as far down as possible, and then cut off the excess.
  3. Rotate arm and enjoy a piece of Archimedes' mind with a modern touch.
  4. Add oil if needed.

Trammel of Archimedes Dating back to a documented 1900's, the trammel of Archimedes is a mix between math and engineering. The math is rather complex, here is an excerpt from Wikipedia: "Let C be the outer end of the rod, and A, B be the pivots of the sliders. Let p and q be the distances from A to B and B to C, respectively. Let us assume that sliders A and B move along the y and x coordinate axes, respectively. When the rod makes an angle θ with the x-axis, the coordinates of point C are given by x = (p + q)cosθ
y = q sin θ These are in the form of the standard parametric equations for an ellipse in canonical position. The further equation x^2 / (p + q)^2 + y^2 / q^2 = 1 is immediate as well." Combining the math and engineering, you get a cool toy/tool that moves in an interesting way while creating an ellipse.

Basics:
  • Print out all pieces, teaching about the process of 3D printing in the process
  • Once printed, assemble and demonstrate the way it moves.
  • Then teach the math, and the elliptical movement.

• All printed parts
  • 2 wooden toothpicks

8/20/2017

Added a cut down Base for printing with less material: "Base-Reduced.stl"

title: 8mm Fit Test Gauge for Guiding Rods
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I came up with this pieces when I was about to print my redesigned pieces for AM8 frame. I didn't want to spend half a roll of PLA to see how the bars didn't fit or were too loose.

Therefore, I created this piece which ranges from 8.1 to 8.9mm (0.1mm step). The arrow points from 8.1 to 8.2mm.

.1 > .2 .3
.4 .5 .6
.7 .8 .9

Just print this piece, and check with a guiding rod which of the holes achieves the best fit for your purpose.

In my case, 8.4mm turned out to be the best diameter for tight fit, but this may vary upon your filament, nozzle, flowrate...

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/b9AMg5DZPcK

Updated STL Files, Exported with 1mm per unit
This puzzle you can either 3D print or make using some M16 & M8 Brass nuts and bolts, you will also need a 4mm x 2mm round neodymium magnet. and a 10mm x 4mm steel rod (cut a piece of 4mm nail) Thanks to Grabcad User Heatniks for the original bolt and nut drawings.
http://grabcad.com/heatnix The origional idea for this puzzle is based on a puzzle from "homemade puzzles"
http://homepage.ntlworld.com/bruce.viney/Bolt%20Puzzles%20Secrets.pdf You can find more detailed instructions here:
http://www.instructables.com/id/Brass-Bolt-Puzzle/

How it works: Get the washer off the bolt.
The idea is the magnet is glued into the top section of the main bolt with epoxy. Which will hold the steel rod in place when the assembly is together. To open the puzzle you need to slam the base on a hard surface. to allow you to remove the other parts of the puzzle so you can remove the washer.

description.text:
A multi-part spool holder/suspender that I designed in Tinkercad because I only had 2 ball bearings on me, and couldn't make the TUSH holder. Then I changed it so it doesn't need ball bearings anymore.

You can change reels by removing the reel suspenders (the bits the spool slides on) and lifting one side of the crossbar off to remove or change the spool.
The holders are adjustable and you can use it with or without ball bearings.

Print:
4x suspender foot
2x suspender brace
1x suspender crossbar
2x suspender holder OR suspender holder ballbearing (if you have large inner-diameter spools and want to use ball bearings)

Feedback appreciated!

I made this

I had an 18" sprinkler riser pipe in my closet which I decided to put to use as a spool holder. It wouldn't quite reach the full width of the frame, so I needed a slightly extended bracket to attach it. I also wanted it to be strong enough to hang several spools on if necessary. You'll need to print two pieces - one for each side. You'll also need a pipe, rod, or shaft of some sort 18" long and around 3/4" diameter. I designed it in Fusion 360 for my Folger Tech FT-5, but it should work on any similar printer with appropriate adjustments to the length of the pipe.

title: Mansions of Madness Figure Base
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A figure and token holder for Mansions of Madness. A friend of mine bought the game used recently, and one of the bases had a busted clip. Figured it would be easy enough to model and print.

The windows don't perfectly align to the numbers on the token, but the original token doesn't quite line up either, and the friend I was doing this for preferred authenticity.

I don't actually own any of the various Lovecraft-themed games, but I know there's some inter-compatibility with miniatures. If this works for another game, let me know so I can add it to the tags.

It's a pretty firm fit as printed - see the section on that.

Printer:

Monoprice Select Mini v1

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1mm

Notes:

I found I got the best results with the least post-processing printing it vertical with support type set to 'lines' and support density set to 10% in Cura, with the part just off center in my print area so that the supports formed a thin sheet in the windows of the part (use the layer view and shift it about 1/4mm at a time until you hit it).

Printing it flat on the mostly solid side worked, but the fit was a bit tighter, getting the supports out was a bit of a pain, and the surface finish wasn't quite as good, although it did print much faster. You might want to look into scaling it just a small amount if you print flat.

description.text:
This frame that will hold a standard sized shade #14 welders glass filter for viewing the solar eclipse, or for general sun observation.

The lens size is 2" x 4.25". BE SURE TO USE ONLY SHADE #14. See the photo, and you will know what to ask for.

I was able to obtain the lens from a local welders supply shop, who still had a good supply as of Aug 15 2017. The sun will look greenish, but otherwise good optical quality. For reference, I paid $3.25 for the lens, so when you add in the tip, you will only be out $6.25! (just saying).

The lens is deigned to snap in from the FRONT of the frame (the side with raised lettering). Be careful, but some force may be needed. PRESS ONLY ON THE CORNERS

1) Insert and fully seat 2 of the side corners from the front of the frame.
2) Flip the frame over (text side down) and place on a non-scratch surface.
3) Firmly press down on the 2 remaining corners.
4) Flip over and verify all 4 corners are fully seated.

If the frame is too tight some filing may be needed. If too loose, add a drop of glue or ABS slurry to each FRONT corner.

I added 2 slots for an elastic strap, but this is probably not a good idea, as the #14 lens is so dark, the ONLY thing you can see is the sun! Also, you really should not stare for more than 10 seconds at a time, even with the proper protection. Your eyes are way to valuable to take chances. DO NOT USE WITH BINOCULARS OR ANY OTHER TYPE OF MAGNIFYING LENSES

PLEASE DON'T EVEN THINK ABOUT USING THIS WITH ANYTHING OTHER THAN #14 SHADE WELDERS LENS.

Also, please search the internet for eclipse viewing precautions. I am only providing a frame design. Use at your own risk.

Enjoy the show!!

I wanted to provide some shade around the smallish lens, to help prevent accidental direct sun exposure. This also helps keep fingerprints off the lens, and makes the lens easier to pass around and share with others. The simplistic design also works well for eyeglass wearers. It might also protect the lens from a fall, but I did not test that!

I used a .3 layer height, as there is not much detail. No support. I printed mine in ABS, but any material will work. Just use all normal warping precautions. A darker color will provide the best "extra shade" protection.

title: Control Panel and Cable Chain rig for RB1

description.text:
This will work on a RB1 Regular. However, as I was still learning Fusion 360 at the time, some parts came out a little off and once I got them installed I saw no reason to redesign them to perfection. If it works, Don't fix it.
The MKs 1.4 Main Board is mounted in the control panel while the power supplies are external and mounted in the equipment rack The Beast sits on.
It supports mounting a cooling fan on either end of the control panel with a remote SD card slot and LCD panel in the front.
This was designed to work on Peter Stoneham's Single Extruder mount with a one off perfboard X axis PCB, so you will need to either fabricate your own board, or modify the X Axis Terminus to fit your board.

description.text:
We have an upright "volcano" style vaporizer that uses forced air and fills bags.

The top half of the capsule was broken. The metal capsule components were fine, but it no longer locked securely closed. This made sure that every time you removed a bag, it spilled the capsule.

I spent a few evenings playing in graphSCAD until I got it right for the machine in question. Feel free to edit the graphscad files to suit your machine. The machine in question has 3 locking tabs and a ring near the top of the metal capsule's "chimney".

Sorry if this doesn't make much sense, but maybe someone else can utilize it. Included is a tip for attaching a bag or hose.

description.text:
Just uploaded this thingy... It hasn't been printed yet or tested...
It should easily snap on a 25mm conduit. The minimal distance in the opening is just under 24mm. Check the Ultimaker thingy (also a guess-thingy).

If you have some small metal rods you can add a TY-rap to tighten it to the conduit.

P.S. groter means bigger (diameter) If you are the first, YOU ARE alpha tester !!! So start with one print and enlighten the community with your feedback on the thingy, before printing the rest. The printed part had 0.2mm clearing on the diameter.

STEP 1. Sit down and eat an apple while staring at your project.
STEP 2. Make a basic functional thingy.
STEP 3. Improve the strength of the model where needed (getting way to serious here)
STEP 4. Improve the functionality to your liking.

Uhm... Just realized I wanted to sneak in a guide for the end-switch cable.

STEP 5. Get back to the drawing board and edit that model...

This is a Rhombic Dodecahedron created in OpenScad. It has 12 consequences inscribed; one per side.

These read...
"Do chores", Public service", "No screen time", "Lose tablet", "No car", "Early to bed", "Lose phone", "No sweets", "Grounded", "Clean room", "Free pass", and "Mom's choice"

Kids roll and face their judgement. Karma does the rest.

I have been practicing doing bunny hops and I thought it would be nice to have something to practice hopping over that will not cause damage to me or my bike if I mess up.

DIRECTIONS:

  • Print 2 of each of the base and top parts.

This is constructed with standard 1/2" ID PVC (21.5mm OD). The base pieces are screwed into short pieces of 2"x4" studs. The cross bar is a 48" fiberglass driveway marker rod. The holders for the cross bar are just snapped onto the 1/2" PVC at the appropriate height. Height can easily be adjusted by moving the holders to whatever height you would like.

title: ReMixed Mount and Nozzle for 800 Watt Water Cooled CNC Spindle!
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The original is an amazing piece of design work and kudos to the designer the only two issues I had where (1) the mount didn't fit my 800 watt water cooled spindle on my 3040 CNC and (2) the nozzle printed, but because of the over hang I did not like the "finish" and yes I am very picky! So to fix these two issues I remixed the mount and and split the nozzle in half to print as two pieces and just glued them together. If you don't want to do this, simply print the original from (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:536091) instead. As in that download are other attachments worth looking at too.

I also used a #10 Magic Nut Thing (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2477078) as the cinch, however you can use that what ever you want. I just think the Magic Nut Thing makse the design look nicer and its quick to take on and off...

Also, please follow us on Thingiverse and give this a like if this came in handy and for more information on this project, please visit us at http://www.DIY3DTech.com as well as subscribe to our YouTube Channel at http://YouTube.DIY3DTech.com along with a visit to our drone site and YouTube channel at http://video-drone.DIY3DTech.com

If you are looking for one of a kind swag shop for yourself or a Maker Geek friend, visit our swag shop at http://Swag.DIY3DTech.com for unique 3D Printing, Laser Cutting and CNC swag! Too, if you want a behind the scene look at what we are working on be sure to follow us on Instagram (https://www.instagram.com/diy3dtech/)!

description.text:
I made this tripod for my Sci Fi Slug Thrower model. https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2483959 The Slug Thrower is made for 15mm - 18mm scale but the tripod could work up to 28mm I suppose. You can use the included mount if you want to put a hole in it to accept the 3mm post. There's not a lot of detail so if you scale it up more than 28mm you might want to remix it and add some.

If you want to make your own mount, the two rectangle holes are 2x4mm with 2mm spacing. The holes are a little oversized, though, to make it easy to insert and remove. Print at .2mm and make sure not to overextrude or things might be too tight. Once assembled, you can glue everything in place or leave it adjustable.

When you snap it together, make sure you insert the joints straight in and note where the center vertical support piece is on the ball joints.

title: Battle Damaged Golden Wing Crest Shield [Dark Souls III]

description.text: This is the first one I've made from scratch. It's roughly 3 ft tall and 1.5 ft wide. Tried to make it look like it's been in the actual world of dark souls. Filled with holes from arrows, scratches from enemies, dents from blunt weapons, etc. I didn't add the rivets around the outer edge as I was afraid about how they would turn out when printing. So you'll either have to add them to the model or post-print.

author: DedarkZ

description.text: i hope you like it

Here is a Brachistochrone curve that you can race two marbles from different points along the curve and see they meet at the bottom at the same time.

The tracks are curved, so the marbles should stay along the middle of the path.

The orientation of the print is important. You want the grains to point in the direction of the marble's path (so there's little resistance along the path from different points). You can print another orientation, but sanding will then be required.

I have yet to print this, but I believe the curves are subtle enough not to require supports.
Original design was by SteveMachine. I just made his a bit slimmer and filleted some edges to make it look less bocky.

author: miodice

title: The Loop De Loop (aka Impossible Japanese) Puzzle

description.text:
This is probably the highest quality version of the "Impossible Japanese Puzzle" on thingiverse as of late. The model is comprised of four printed parts, 3/8 inch braided rope, 1/2 inch oak wood dowel, and a 2" steel ring [All non-printed parts are from Home Depot]. I discovered the puzzle on youtube and wanted to get one for myself, but I found that they're a bit small and not of the highest quality. So naturally I knew I could build it better. This is my rendition of the Loop De Loop Puzzle. It's about 150% larger than the version you can buy and is designed with handling in mind. It also looks very clean and simple so that it can actually also be a display piece unlike other versions on thingiverse. The scale, in my opinion is what I think sets this specific puzzle apart. It's got a substantial look and feel to it, and is large enough to set on a table and fiddle with for a long time. It doesn't have that "cheap one-trick-3D-printed-trinket" feel. Don't let its looks distract you from the challenge though; happy puzzling!

Printed on an Ultimaker 2+ at 50mm/s and 0.1mm layer height. Supports on the base and headpiece for the holes. Print the headpiece laying flat. I'll upload a picture of the actual puzzle when I get the chance; I'm currently lending it to a friend while he struggles to solve it.

This puzzle can be purchased on PuzzleMaster's website, where it is officially named the Loop De Loop: https://www.puzzlemaster.ca/browse/wood/woodpuzzlemaster/21-loop-de-loop

ASSEMBLY INSTRUCTIONS:

Print all parts in whichever color you like. It's originally designed for a blue-red-green color scheme. Next melt SLIGHTLY the rope at one end so that the flange created acts as a stop on the bottom of the base. Make sure that this flange is enough to stop even harsh tugs on the rope from the other end. Fill the rest of the hole with hot glue. String on the spheres, ring, and run the rope through the headpiece like the original puzzle [you can look at it on PuzzleMaster's website]. 1.5-2ft of rope should be enough for the puzzle to function, but feel free to fine tune it so that the length is just right. I squish an index card flat on the hot glue plugs in the base so that it sits flat and looks nice. When the glue cools you can rub it off with a bit of water to get a clean matte finish on the glue. Glue the dowel with superglue, gorilla glue, whatever you want. Clamping will ensure a strong puzzle. Note that the base and headpiece might be a little tight-fitting when attached to the wooden dowel. Try not to cut into the model to remedy this! I chose wood because it can be sanded slimmer and look nice at the same time. The spheres should not let the ring pass through-- they are only for indicating the different sides. If they do (or if it is close enough that people keep thinking it will fit through) you can model your own spheres larger.

If you build one, consider uploading a make. Thanks.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1 - 0.2mm layer height

Infill:

10-20%, the base can be less

title: The Stowage Project
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
!!!!!!PLEASE READ THE DESCRIPTION!!!!!!!!

This is a highly experimental collection of 1:100 tank stowage pieces. These are designed to be added to already existing tank models and printed with them. It is unlikely that they will print on there own. Some of these will not print on a standard abs/pla printer. This is an experiment to determine both the viability of custom stowage tank models and 3D printed infantry. Most 3D modeling programs will allow you to drag and position these in an assembly. Mesh-mixer is a free example of one of these 3D modeling programs.

I've always been interested in doing some "pimped out" tanks with loads of crew storage on them. unfortunately this would require not only a lot of modeling work but a lot of time positioning the stowage items. So I handled the modeling parts I'm asking you guys to handle the rest. IF YOU MAKE A STOWAGE VEHICLE PLEASE POST THE FILES AS A REMIX HERE.

author: TigerAce1945

description.text:
This is a variant of the other tensioner I made for CNC hot wire cutter.
It doesn't build as much in height.
It is used to keep the hot wire tension even if the axes on the cnc machine moves.
The servo is modified to rotate 360 degrees and the controller is an Arduino pro mini.
The code I made for it is simple and the one thing that one may have to change is the "map(a,b,c,d)" command to suit.
Code included below.

#include <Servo.h>

Servo servo;

const int potPin= A0;
const int servoPin= 5;
const int LED= 13;

void setup(){
    pinMode(potPin, INPUT);
    pinMode(servoPin, OUTPUT);

    servo.attach(servoPin);
    //Serial.begin(9600); //Only for testing.
}

void loop(){
    int potAngle= analogRead(potPin);

    potAngle= map(potAngle, 0, 800, 0, 180); //To centre the servo with this potentiometer, 
the full range is not used in this particular case.

    servo.write(potAngle);    

    if(potAngle == 90){ //Indicate when servo is centered and stationary.
        digitalWrite(LED, HIGH);
    }
    else{
        digitalWrite(LED, LOW);
    }

    //Serial.println(potAngle); //Only for testing.

    delay(15); //15 is normal and about 200 at testing.

}

OpenDungeonTiles: Roughstone Kits v1

Here are some updated full kits only.
V1: Update is the lock - it is now smaller length wise - otherwise they stick out of the exterior walls.
V1: The doors have edge stones around them
V1: The slide opening for the gate is slightly larger on the walls with the doors.

Assembly:
Walls take 5mm magnetic spheres
Floors take 3mm magnetic spheres
Bases take 5mm magnetic spheres
Insert 5mm magnetic spheres into the 2 holes, glue thinner piece on top. When placing other parts onto the base, the thinner glued on part should be on the bottom. (I am working on assembly video/instructions)

Open Forge Compatible.
Open Lock Compatible (Note: You must use the lock in my files it is thinner)

Glossary:
FullKit
Files marked FULLKIT at the beginning are all the pieces you need to assembly for a full base tiles/corner tile/wall tiles etc... They usually include the base, basecap, floor, floorcap, and walls with wallcap if applicable.
Kit
Files marked KIT at the beginning are the pieces you need to assembly a full tile without the base pieces (because there is a base kit, this https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2463765)
KITDUAL
The is the same as a kit, but a files that contains two copies of the part. Cut down on copy paste in slicers.
Something else
These are the individual pieces if you wish to print a single part of the tile. Not all the files are done for these, and you may have to pull them out of the kits. (working on this)

Questions - use the comments, send me a message here or on patreon.

Hello I have set up a Patreon: https://www.patreon.com/opendungeontiles
Why go here, well it helps me give free models to the community and there is even a spot for limited custom requests!

title: Felt Pad Adapter for Scandinavian Design Chair

description.text:
This adapter allows felt pads to be securely attached to my Scandinavian Design chair (style name unknown). Because the metal chair legs have an unusual oval shape, the standard felt pads in circle shapes would not fit. Furthermore, the standard felt pads would come off after repeated use because its back is not sticky enough. Therefore, I design this adapter with a recessed area to physically grab on to the back of the felt pad during side-to-side movement.

A heavy duty felt pad from Home Depot with approx. 1.5mm backing is used. Item name:
Everbilt 4-1/2 in. x 6 in. Heavy Duty Self-Adhesive Felt Blankets (2 per Pack) for $3

I had to cut the felt pad by hand. To get the proper shape, I also design a marking template.

Future improvement: I hope to find thicker pads. This cut-it-yourself pad is thin and may wear out quickly.

title: FT Gremlin Backpack Mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Needed a way to strap down my new Flight Test Gremlin to my backpack for easy transport and took a cue from the Tiny Whoop Bracket.

Add hoops and straps instead of hooks (also prints much better, no support needed) and this is the result.

You then just need to supply a velcro batter strap that I'm sure you have lying around, a short piece of cord, print out a cord stop and strap it to your backpack!

I have 2 designs, one with a large hole or one with slots. one should suit your needs!

Tips:
When choosing the cord, make sure that a simple overhand knot can fit through the hole in both the print and cord toggle. Strap down your quad like you would normally, tighten down the toggle then tie a simple overhand knot just past the toggle, this could save everything coming apart in a jolt or drop! Simple safety measure!

title: Minecraft Raspberry Pi Case with lights

description.text:
:UPDATE 8/18/17:
Schematic for the LED array posted.

I installed them with the colors staggered somewhat evenly

They are currently connected through the 3.3v power. I am thinking I may want to test it at 5v, as the lights aren't quite as bright as I had hoped.

              Edit 2:

Tried it through 5v. I like it better... posted both schematics, use whichever you prefer. The only difference is whether you connect the power wire through pin 1 or pin 2.

              Edit 3:

Server is up and running. Lights are lighting. 100% finished.

:UPDATE 08/17/17:
The lights are working!

I modified the code from this tutorial to make the lights do what I wanted them to do:
https://www.sunfounder.com/learn/Super_Kit_V2_for_RaspberryPi/lesson-3-flowing-led-lights-super-kit-for-raspberrypi.html

The script needs to run at startup:
https://www.raspberrypi.org/documentation/linux/usage/rc-local.md

I am using this write-up to set-up the server, but I haven't finished yet:
http://lemire.me/blog/2016/04/02/setting-up-a-robust-minecraft-server-on-a-raspberry-pi/

I will work on the server part tomorrow. I will also post the schematic and more pictures tomorrow.

08/16/17
Planning for this to have lights inside that switch from red (redstone) yellow (gold) blue (lapiz) and white (diamonds)

I have not finished the internals for that, but I should have done by tomorrow evening.

In the meantime, here is the case with the PI mount inside,

I designed this to house my family Minecraft server. It seemed appropriate... but I also wanted it to double as a spiffy nightlight.

comments.text: Hey, like the idea. I was thinking something similar as a cheaper alternative to any other system for minecraft for the kids, but this is really cool!
comments.author: Varsilence

comments.text: thanks! If you make it, I would love to see how it turns out!

description.text:
This project is called the Zip Tool. I designed it to allow you to push zip ties from one side. It will curve the zip tie and feed it back to you on the same side in another hole. This is useful for putting zip ties on the inner back plate (or anywhere really) of an iMade3D Jelly Box (or any wire management system--I think). It takes a little to learn how to align it quickly, but it is a really cool tool once you figure it out.

You can change colors at layers 15 and 45 (3D printing at 200 microns) and it will allow you to see a color line that will help you align your Zip Tool.

Note for enthusiasts that will actually print this, using black makes it nearly impossible to align the holes, because it is hard to see.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

200

Infill:

20

Notes:

There are a few 90 degree over hangs. Make sure your fan is on. Don't print with supports or the tool will not work correctly.

Why did I design this?

I wanted to break the zip tie time record on Step 3 of the Jelly Box build. You can find this record here: http://docs.imade3d.com/Guide/Electronics/180

The record now belongs to me at 2'43", but the guide has not been updated yet.

Jelly Box 18 Zip Tie Pre-Install Record, 2'43" (Aug 10, 2017 10:22pm)

description.text:
Meant to be displayed near Confederate monuments to give proper historical context. Many of these monuments speak only of the bravely, virtue and "noble cause" of the Confederacy. They intentionally do not mention the institution by name that the Confederacy fought to preserve or the cruel, inhumane conditions that slaves were trapped in. The United Daughters of the Confederacy was the organization that put up the majority of these statues, they have throughout the years been frequently accused of history revisionism and have alleged ties to white supremacists.

Slavery Text:
"It was not rare for a slave's children to be sold, either for profit or punishment. Overseers were allowed to relentlessly torture and whip slaves without repercussion, this was often done to break their will and inspire obedience. While it was illegal to kill a slave, it happened frequently and these laws were rarely enforced. Some slaves were killed merely for disobedience. It was illegal to teach slaves how to read and slaves could not sue a white or even testify in court against a white. Female slaves were a frequent target of rape. Escaped slaves were hung, usually in a public place to serve as an example.

Slavery had strong support in the South, even among non-slave owning whites. It was seen as a sign of wealth that poor whites desired to achieve."

Texas Text:
"We hold as undeniable truths that the governments of the various States, and of the confederacy itself, were established exclusively by the white race, for themselves and their posterity; that the African race had no agency in their establishment; that they were rightfully held and regarded as an inferior and dependent race, and in that condition only could their existence in this country be rendered beneficial or tolerable." - A Declaration of the Causes which Impel the State of Texas to Secede, February 1861

Confederacy Constitution Text:
"No bill of attainder, ex post facto law, or law denying or impairing the right of property in negro slaves shall be passed." - Constitution of the Confederate States of America, March 1861

Cornerstone Speech Text:
"Our new government is founded...upon the great truth that the negro is not equal to the white man; that slavery subordination to the superior race is his natural and normal condition. This, our new government, is the first, in the history of the world, based upon this great physical, philosophical, and moral truth." - Alexander H. Stephens (Vice President of the Confederacy), March 1861

Step 1: Locate A Confederate Monument

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_monuments_and_memorials_of_the_Confederate_States_of_America

Step 2: Gather Supplies
  • Hex Bolt X 4 ($1.60) - http://www.homedepot.com/p/Everbilt-5-16-in-18-tpi-x-4-in-Zinc-Plated-Hex-Bolt-800776/204645554
  • Nut X 4 ($0.44) - http://www.homedepot.com/p/Everbilt-5-16-in-Zinc-Plated-Coarse-Threaded-Hex-Nut-801746/204647888
  • Bag of Concrete ($5.40) - http://www.homedepot.com/p/Quikrete-80-lb-Crack-Resistant-Concrete-100680/100318448
  • Cardboard box ($2.12) - http://www.homedepot.com/p/The-Home-Depot-22-in-L-x-21-in-W-x-22-in-D-Extra-Large-Box-1001015/202518472
  • Enamel ($3.76) - http://www.homedepot.com/p/Rust-Oleum-Specialty-12-oz-Appliance-Epoxy-Gloss-Black-Spray-Paint-7886830/100141519
Step 3: Construction

Spray enamel onto the inside of the cardboard box and let dry. Place bolts through plaque and secure with nuts. Travel to site. Pour concrete into the coated cardboard box and add water, mix with shovel. Smooth out the top of the concrete. Insert the plaque into the concrete, make sure back is slightly indented into the surface of the concrete.

Be sure to place the plaque near but not on the monument because you could be charged with "defacing" even if you cause no damage. You're exercising freedom of speech and you don't want it be to construed as vandalism.

title: Raspberry Pi Model B+ PCB Assembly w/ SD slot

description.text:
Remixed to add an SD card reader.

I didn't know where to get my hands on an SD slot CAD file so I created the SD reader slot by copying the slot on my Pi 3 as best I could. I did NOT create any of the rest of the Raspberry Pi model.

Comes in 2 versions, one with just the SD slot, and one with an SD card in the slot.

update: STEP file uploaded (thanks fusion360)

Please don't ask for the step file, for some reason FreeCAD won't export anything when I try to export the STEP (it normally works fine), probably because I'm using the unstable dev version 0.17. I would upload the STEP if I could (I'll try again with a different build of FreeCAD).

Original Pi model: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:412639

Case model I used to see if the SD slot was in roughly the right place: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:922740

Note: I measured the SD position off of a Raspberry Pi 3, and the SD slot on the Pi3 is slightly different to the Pi2 (it doesn't click in and out, it's just a push fit) so I'm not 100% certain of the size/position but I think they're in the same spot (and importing the case's STL, the sd slot does seem to fit). I couldn't seem to find any mechanical drawings of the SD card's exact position.

Custom printer from the year 4527

0.01nm

yes

description.text:
Had printed up one of the many other hinged filters on here and after a few removals, the clip broke. A binder clip fixed that, but it was annoying.

Made this quick little filament filter that's held together with magnets. Easy to take off and put on. No clips to break. Fusion 360 source file included.

Been using this one for a couple months now and it works quite well for cleaning the dust off filament. A bonus I have found from the design is that when not in use, the magnets allow it to be stored on the extruder stepper or the metal side of the printer when not in use.

What you will need:
2x prints of each part.
8x 3mm diameter 4mm tall cylindrical magnets. (can be acquired on ebay for a couple money units)
2 strips of your favorite flavor of dust cloth (I used Swifter).

Assembly:
Press the magnets into the holes. Be sure to have them the right way up with all north poles up one side and south up on the other. If you get it wrong, it will do the opposite of holding itself together.
Bent the "spring" parts up slightly on either side of the ridges.
Wrap a strip of dust cloth around the "spring".
Fit the "spring" under the clips on either side of the holder.

The dust cloths last a long time in this thing and can be rotated around the "spring" part when it dirty.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 or lower

Infill:

Doesn't matter, small and thin enough to print solid easily

I'm not fully happy with the design of the "springs" on this. I would like to have it as single part, but couldn't quickly see a way that wouldn't require difficult to remove supports. Making this as WIP as I have not done much testing so far.

About 2 months later: This has been working well. Calling this done for now.

comments.text: Thanks for sharing! I have small stack of these magnets! Finally found a good use for them!

description.text:
In 2016 I had a project for one of my university assignments, the primary goal was to establish some kind of online web presence, a colleague and I came up with the presence called "Where the Science Happens" or WSH, the goal was to show using VR 360 degree navigatable panorama style images to showcase the spaces that scientists work in.

The project was a failure however the result was an interesting learning and design experience in Virtual Reality and Imaging.

A week of digital design resulted in a VR Rig design with the goals that it must be:

  • Fits and utilizes the cheap action camera style clone SJCAM
  • Full 360 Degree View
  • Uses 6 cameras
  • Tripod Mountable
  • Easily 3D Printable
  • Use as little material as possible
  • built in ports for charging and SD Card access

The overall design is based on a cube with chamfered corners and edges and consists of 3 pieces that make up the overall design, it uses knurled inserts to allow screws for securing the intersections of different parts, the design was rushed due to time restriction and lacks refinement in a lot of areas, however due to alternative projects I have released the design files online.

The FacePlate - Responsible for housing the insertable cameras and has the most area of the object

Corner Hex Plates - there consists of 3 different hex plates a blank connecting piece, one with 2 holes for access to the USB ports on the cameras and a third that has a connecting screw for the tripod.

Flat Edges - these mainly are connecting piece designed for rigidity.

I hope that others may be able to improve and remix this design to improve it, I hope to find some time to enable the installation of a few of the ideas I had in particular an integrated USB Hub that allows charging of all cameras from the mains as well as accessing all SD Cards at once and possibly some kind of script/program that grabs and stitches all photos together.

You can find this project and others on my blog:
curiosityplace.wordpress.com

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

No

No

0.1

20%

Notes:

The frame is currently too thin and is weakened when inserting the knurled inserts.

Construction

To construct begin by inserting knurled inserts in the holes on each base plate, then screw in the corresponding sides and hexes, leave a base plate edge and corner off in order to insert all the required wires.

This is a carry case for the one blade. It fits neatly inside and is held by built in clips so that it doesn't rattle around.

The base, acts as a handy stand if you want to leave it in the bathroom

The second file is an extra attachment that can store up to 3 one blade attachments so you don't lose them.
